dialogues.KURTZ:
[1]I want that napalm dropped in the trees -- spread it among the branches. We'll give you a flare -- an orange one -- bright orange. We'd also like some white phosporous, Blue Delta. White phosporous, give it to me. 
[2]I'm Kurtz. 
[3]At ease... Sit down. 
[4]Why did you come to ... my province. 
[5]You were not coming here, to see me? 
[6]You came up my river -- in that small boat. So simple. I always thought the final justice would come from the sky, like we did. You are the final justice, aren't you? 
[7]What other reason could you have come? A Captain. Ranger. Paratrooper. Graduate of the Recondo School. Am I right about these things? 
[8]Then the Agency approached you. Maybe in a bar in Quinon or Pleiku. Simple. A year's pay for one life. Perhaps a village elder, or a tax collector. Nobody's orders but your own. Exciting work. 
[9]You've spent tome at the Royal Tracking School of Malaysia. I can tell from the way the laces on your boots are tied. I understand you, Captain. We understand each other. 
[10]Yes. 
[11]Do you know me ? 
[12]Yeah, I can see that. He's fuckin nuts -- 
[13]I'm awake. 
[14]You. Get out. 
[15]I said get the fuck out ! I'm going to kill the little weirdo myself tomorrow. He´s only stayed alive this long because he's a good orderly and medic. He knows how to use a hypodermic. 
[16]That's right, the little gook- pricks. But they are noble little gook-pricks, noble. Because they fight with their guts, like animals. And for an idea ! That's rich. We fight with ingenious machines and fire, like Gods, and for nothing. But I'll call in a major blotto airstrike tonight. We'll have ourselves a helluva airstrike tonight, a lightshow. How do you like The Doors': 'C'mon Baby Light My Fire...' 
[17]Do you? 
[18]I love it. 
[19]No. My thinking is clear. But my soul has gone mad. 
[20]My gut -- Oh, Christ, my gut ! 
[21]Oh shit -- on the table; morphine. 
[22]You see how stupid it would have been to blow out my brains? I'm dying from the gut anyway. 
[23]No -- I don't want to sleep. I want to think. Water. Give me water. 
[24]Still playing by the rules. You're a damn good kiler. 
[25]How's yours? 
[26]Pain is easy to handle -- but nobility.. the nobility of a man is judged by how much Truth he can handle. 
[27]The truth that you were sent here to murder me, ans so far you haven't done it. And do you know why? Yes, you know why. Your mission makes about as much sense as those idiots who sent you on it. Asshole ! Schmuck ! How long does it take you to figure out that nobody knows what they're doing here. Except me. 
[28]Gimme water. 
[29]You know what you're doing? You are interfering with my plans ! 
[30]This water's got Moonby's acid in it -- 
[31]Drink it -- drink it for tonight. Think of it. A whole regiment of those shitty little Cong -- War. Total war -- war like you've never known it. It's beautiful -- you'll love it. Trust me. 
[32]Goddamn -- You've gotta dig napalm on Speed, too. It's spectacular, you'll see. 
[33]Look into the jungle. You can't -- it's too terrible. You have to smear yourself with warpaint to look at it -- you have to be a cannibal. That's why warpaint was invented. Then it becomes your jungle. 
[34]Because of all the things we do, the thing we do best -- is lie. 
[35]Oh Captain, that is so true. 
[36]You could never figure it because it doesn't make sense. 
[37]I'll tell you what makes sense ! Air strikes ! White Phosphorus ! Napalm ! We'll bomb the shit out of them if they don't do what we want. 
[38]Think of it -- for years, millions of years, savages with pathetic painted faces were scared shitless that fire would rain down from the sky. And goddamn, we made it happen. God  bless  Dow  ! 
[39]Mini-gun. Colby. Sergeant. Mini-gun. 
[40]Claymores, claymores. 
[41]Charles ! 
[42]Go away -- hide yourself. 
[43]Going back  - to the jungle to die. 
[44]I had immense plans. 
[45]I was on threshold of great things. 
[46]Don't. Don't frighten them away. 
[47]Do I not? 
[48]My river... my people... my jungle... my wife... ... my death. 
[49]Yes... 
[50]The horror, the horror. 
[51]The horror ! The horror !

dialogues.GASTON:
[1]Who is the commanding officer? 
[2]Philippe -- 
[3]Fifty calibers, eh, Captain -- 
[4]Entirely unnecessary, Captain. 
[5]We share a common enemy -- you are our guests. I am Gaston de marais -- this is my family's plantation. It has been such for 121 years. It will be such after I die. This is my son, Philippe -- he has fought in Algeria and held the rank of Captain. And Henry LeFevre -- a sergeant; he was at Dien Bien Phu. My personal servant, Tran Van Kac --- 
[6]My youngest son -- Christian -- 
[7]Christian's wife -- Ann-Marie -- 
[8]And my youngest daughter -- Claudine. 
[9]We took them from the dead. Now -- I assume you want to rest, to shower. We'll attend to your repairs after dinner. 
[10]A man of war is never bothered to aid an ally -- you will follow me, Captain. 
[11]Of course, Captain -- an unfortunate necessity. 
[12]A suitable accomodation for your men, captain -- you will, of course, be quartered with us -- 
[13]Captain, this way. 
[14]Magnificent, eh, Captain? 
[15]It is very good -- there is no current -- It is very good. I have never seen one like it in all Indochina. I was in Paris when it arrived -- do you know what might have caused -- 
[16]No, I've seen those in Normandy. This is much better. My country -- my country could never originate this. Magnificent. 
[17]Roxanne, I hope you are feeling better. 
[18]May I present Captain Willard? He is of a paratroop regiment. You know the difference between a paratrooper and a regular soldier, don't you , my dear? 
[19]Attacks repulsed, as I was saying. This is only  for this war, Captain. Viet Cong -- 54; North Vietnamese regular forces -- 15; South Vietnamese -- 28 -- regular forces and otherwise. Americain -- 6. Of course, they were, perhaps, mistakes, Captain. 
[20]Captain? 
[21]We will never 'evacuate', Captain -- this is our home. Indochina is ours; it has been so for a hundred and twenty-one years, there is something to say for that. 
[22]But we civilized it. A place belongs to those who bring light to it, don't you agree. 
[23]Upriver? Why upriver? There is nothing there, only jungle. 
[24]When I was a boy, my father would take me there, to hunt. There are a few savages, but no man can live there, no white man. 
[25]We have never heard of him. 
[26]Bon nuit, Roxanne -- bon nuit, Captain. 
[27]Two of my men deserted last night. It happens from time to time. I assume my daughter told you of our conditions. 
[28]We endure, captain -- you can blow up the house and we will live in the cellar -- destroy that and we'll dig a hole in the jungle and sleep on it. Burn the forest and we'll hide in the swamp. all the while, we do but one thing -- clean the blood off our bayonets. Au revoir, Captain.

dialogues.ROXANNE:

dialogues.COLONEL:
[1]Okay, Willard, sit down. 
[2]Have you ever seen this officer before, Captain Willard ? 
[3]This gentleman or myself ? 
[4]I believe on your last job you executed a tax collector in Kontum, is that right ? 
[5]You know much about about Special Forces; Green Berets, Captain ? 
[6]Then you can appreciate Command's concern over their -- shall we say 'erratic' methods of operation. I have never favored elite units, Captain, including your paratroopers or whatever. Just because a man jumps out of an airplane or wears a silly hat doesn't give him any priviliges in my book -- not in this man's army. 
[7]We have Special Forces A detachments all along the Cambodian border. Two here and another one here -- twelve or fourteen Americans -- pretty much on their own; they train and motivate Montagnard natives; pick their own operations. If they need something, they call for it, and get it within reason. What we're concerned with is here. 
[8]The A detachment at Nu Mung Ba. It was originally a larger base, built up along the river in an old Cambodian fortress. The area has been relatively quiet for the past two years -- but -- 
[9]... Captain, we know something's going on up there -- Major -- 
[10]About the same time -- large numbers of Montagnards of the M'Nong descent began leaving the area -- this in itself is not unusual since these people have fought with the Rhade Tribe that lived in the area for centuries. But what is unusual is that we began to find Rhade refugees too -- in the same sampans as the M'Nongs. These people aren't afraid of V.C. They've put up with war for twenty years -- but something is driving them out. 
[11]He's commanding the detachment at Nu Mung Ba. 
[12]What was your impression of him ? 
[13]A lame ? 
[14]About what ? 
[15]But why ? 
[16]Well, he's killing now. 
[17]It's got to be Kurtz.
dialogues.MOONBY:
[1]Oh, they're simple enough people. It's good to see you, baby. Nobody has any Winstons? 
[2]This boat's a mess. 
[3]Oh, you don't talk to Colonel Kurtz. You listen to him. God, these are good. I kept these people off you, you know. It wasn't easy. 
[4]Simple. They don't want him to go. 
[5]Pre-Australian, actually. But I'd dig goin' to California. I'm California dreamin'. 
[6]Kurtz. I tell you, that man has enlarged my mind. 
[7]But lemme tell you, he is the most dangerous thing in every way that I've come on so far. He wanted to shoot me. The first thing he said is, 'I'm going to shoot you because you are a deserter.' I said I didn't desert from your army, I deserted from my army. He said, 'I'm going to shoot you just the same.' 
[8]I've asked myself that question. I said to myself, why didn't he shoot me? He didn't shoot me, because I had a stash like you wouldn't believe. I hid it in the jungle; the wealth of the Orient: Marijuana -- Hashish -- Opium -- cocaine -- uncut Heroin; the Gold of the Golden Triangle. and Acid -- I make Koolaid that makes purple Owsley come on like piss. Now I'm Kurtz' own Disciple -- I listen he talks. About everything ! Everything. I forgot there's such a thing as sleep. Everything. Of love, too. 
[9]Oh, no, not what you think... Cosmic love. He made me see things -- things, you know. 
[10]No, Colonel Kurtz couldn't be crazy -- if you heard him talk, just last week, you'd never think he was crazy. 
[11]Those heads, yes. Well, the rebels... 
[12]Right on -- he's been waiting for -- 
[13]His name is... 
[14]Oh, no, don´t say that. 
[15]He's asleep -- don't bother him.
dialogues.KURTZ'S WIFE:
[1]Come in, Captain Willard. 
[2]Can I get anything for you? 
[3]Did you know him very well? 
[4]And you admired him? 
[5]Love him... Yes, it is true. That's the hard part for me... I knew him better than anyone ... I knew him best. 
[6]You were his friend... You must have been, if he had given you this... If he sent you to his home. He was the best this country had -- he was -- 
[7]I'll never get over it -- But I'll always remember him... 
[8]Men looked up to him... He died as he lived... 
[9]Were you with him, when... 
[10]What were they? 
[11]Tell me. 
[12]Tell me what he said.
dialogues.CIVILIAN:
[1]If you're B.L. Willard, 4th Recon Group, we'd like you to come with us. 
[2]The agency. 
[3]Major. 
[4]Would he remember you ? 
[5]You didn't like him. 
[6]What does that mean ? 
[7]The point is that Kurtz or somebody attacked a South Vietnamese Ranger Platoon three days ago. Last week a Recon helicopter was lost in the area -- another took heavy damage -- direct fire from their base camp. 
[8]Ours. 
[9]You can see, of course, the implications, if any of this -- even rumours leaked out. 
[10]Exactly -- you'll go up the Nung River in a Navy P.B.R. -- appear at Nu Mung Ba as if by accident, re-establish your acquintance with Colonel Kurtz, find out what's happened -- and why. Then terminate his command. 
[11]Terminate with extreme prejudice.
dialogues.LIEUTENANT:
[1]You didn't tell me to, sir. 
[2]Captain Willard? 
[3]Captain Willard -- we got these from Nha Thrang two days ago -- they expected you here then -- 
[4]You don't know how happy that makes me, sir. 
[5]Now I can get out a here -- if I can find a way out. 
[6]I'd just clear out as soon as I could if I were you, sir. They're gonna start working on the bridge with torches again. Charlie will start throwing it in hard -- 
[7]It's of strategic importance for keeping the highway into Bat Shan open -- the generals don't like to admit that Bat Shan is surrounded. 
[8]Every night we build it and by 0800 they've blown it up -- it and a lot of good men -- But the generals like to say the road is open -- ha ! Nobody uses that road except Charlie. 
[9]This is the cesspool of hell.
dialogues.COLBY:
[1]What -- happened here. 
[2]NVA regulars. They're coming again tonight. Tet -- their big -- assault. 
[3]Take us back. Take us back ! But, the operation -- the team. Colonel Kurtz has such plans for -- the team. 
[4]I had nothing to do with these operations -- I did not do the planning -- none of us did. It was all Colonel Kurtz -- he was the genius. You'll see -- the genius of our Colonel. He should be made a General, don't you think? A General? It's... 
[5]Who is he? 
[6]There. 
[7]How did they know? 
[8]They're coming to rescue us. They're Medevac. 
[9]Colonel Kurtz, he's dead.
dialogues.GUNNER:
[1]Like a mean motherfucker, sir. 
[2]Gooks.

dialogues.MAJOR:
[1]Very good. 
[2]We didn't need 'em in Korea -- no sir, give me an Ohio farm boy and an M-1 Garand, none of this fancy crap -- no sir. 
[3]Communications naturally dwindled with the lack of V.C. activity, this is routine, expected ... but six months ago communication virtually stopped. 
[4]We communicate with the base infrequently. What they call for are air strikes, immediate -- always at night. And we don't know what or who the air strikes are called on. 
[5]You see, no one has really gone into this area and come back alive. 
[6]Walter Kurtz, Lieutenant Colonel, Special Forces. We understand you knew him. 
[7]That's Colonel Kurtz.
dialogues.VOICE:

dialogues.MIKE:

dialogues.CHARLIE:
